qas.question: What formerly effective tool for international disputes is no longer effective among peer powers?
What great powers have maintained peace?

answers.text: France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States

qas.question: Where have the powers maintained peace in recent years?
What was the last crisis during cold war to escalate world powers?

plausible_answers.text: France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States

qas.question: What countries agree that military force is effective to resolve disputes?

plausible_answers.text: the Cuban missile crisis (1962) during the Cold War

qas.question: During what event did great powers use military force?
Who mentioned that Western great powers still use military force to resolve disputes?
What formerly effective tool for the Cuban missile crisis is no longer effective?

plausible_answers.text: the United Nations and other forums

qas.question: Where have western nations discussed using military force?

context: Another important factor is the apparent consensus among Western great powers that <a0_0><b7_0>military force<b7_0/><a0_0/> is no longer an effective tool of resolving disputes among their peers. This "subset" of great powers – <a1_0><b4_0>France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States<b4_0/><a1_0/> – consider maintaining a "state of peace" as desirable. As evidence, <b6_0>Baron<b6_0/> outlines that since <b5_0>the <a3_0>Cuban missile crisis (1962<a3_0/>) during the Cold War<b5_0/>, these influential Western nations have resolved all disputes among the great powers peacefully at <b8_0>the <a2_0>United Nations and other forums<b8_0/><a2_0/> of international discussion.
